fields.headline: Three models for second chamber
fields.bodyText: Lord Wakeham January 2000 · 550 members to sit in the second chamber · Between 65 and 195 elected members (12-35%) · An independent commission to choose deputies · Commons to remain the dominant body · Should be impossible for one party to secure overall majority · At least 30% should be female, 20% crossbench members, and fair representation for ethnic minority groups. All faiths must also be represented · Political balance to reflect votes cast at general election · Members elected for 15 years · A modest payment to members, according to attendance · Judicial role to continue · Current life peers to choose whether or not to sit in the new body · Should contain members outside politics Lord Irvine November 2001 · 600 members · Dismissal of remaining 92 hereditary peers · 20% directly elected, 60% appointed by the parties, and 20% appointed by independent commission · Link between peerage and Lords' membership. Existing peers to retain membership, but only as a transitional measure · Government control over membership handed to a statutory appointments commission · No changes over bills but powers over subordinate legislation should be changed to one of delay, not veto, to allow the Commons to think again Robin Cook May 2002 · A joint Lords and Commons committee to decide on the second chamber reforms · The committee would then propose the second chamber's composition, ranging from a fully nominated to a fully elected body · Mr Cook is thought to favour a system in which half of the deputies are directly elected · A free vote for MPs and peers on the committee's options · The committee should recommend the transitional strategy for transforming the Lords · Government to bring forward legislation following the report by the joint committee and the opinions of both houses
